The sixth part of the preliminary practices for the perfection of meditation, the second part on clearly verifying the evil roots and natures, explaining the verification of the evil roots and natures.
There are four points.
First, explaining the quantity of afflictions.
Second, explaining the manifestation of the evil roots and natures.
Third, establishing the methods of counteracting.
Fourth, concluding the universal inclusion of the Buddha Dharma.
Now explaining the first, the quantity of afflictions.
As for afflictions,
the Nirvana Sutra says:
Afflictions are evil dharmas.
If one fully discusses evil dharmas,
there are many names and numbers.
Now, briefly discussing five kinds of unwholesome evil dharmas,
combining and opening them to discern the quantity.
The five kinds of unwholesome dharmas are:
1. Unwholesome dharmas of initial and sustained thought,
2. Unwholesome dharmas of greed and desire,
3. Unwholesome dharmas of anger and hatred,
4. Unwholesome dharmas of ignorance and delusion.
The five evil karmic unwholesome dharmas.
If expanded, there are eighty-four thousand.
In terms of their fundamental nature, they are nothing but the three poisons and equal parts.
If the five unwholesome dharmas are combined,
they become the four parts of afflictions.
The three poisons remain as the original three parts.
They all belong to the habitual causes of contemplation and discernment.
Evil karma obstructs the path.
These two unwholesome [parts] are combined into one part.
Why is this so?
Contemplation and discernment are born with the three parts of afflictions.
They can also be said to be the habitual causes of equal parts.
Evil karma obstructs the path.ğŸ”½It belongs to the retributive causes of equal parts.
The habitual and retributive causes are combined and discussed as only one equal part.
The five kinds of unwholesome dharmas,
if generally combined,
there are only four parts.
If discussed in detail, they become eighty-four thousand.
As explained in the MahÄyÄna Treatise.
The affliction of craving desire
has a full twenty-one thousand.
The affliction of anger.
Complete with twenty-one thousand afflictions of stupidity.
Complete with twenty-one thousand.
The affliction of equal parts.
Complete with twenty-one thousand.
The affliction of the four parts.
Combined, they produce eighty-four thousand dust-like afflictions.
The Buddha taught the eighty-four thousand Dharma gates to counter this.
Now, in the middle, it is explained.
Therefore, it only discusses the five kinds of unwholesome evil dharmas.
To discern the characteristics of the arising of the evil fundamental nature.
Why is it so?
Above, the arising of the wholesome fundamental nature is explained.
Since it is distinguished according to the five kinds,
Now, the arising of the evil fundamental nature is explained.
How can it not only be discerned based on the five unwholesome dharmas?
This then is the correspondence of medicine to illness.
The characteristics of the Dharma are equal.
The practitioner wishes to cultivate meditation and samÄdhi.
He must discern it well.
The second is to explain the arising of the evil fundamental nature.
There are practitioners who, when cultivating meditation and samÄdhi,
Have deep and heavy afflictions and defilements.
Although the mind may be still and tranquil,
as explained above,
the inner and outer wholesome dharmas
are not activated at all.
Only the arising of afflictions is perceived.
Therefore, the next is to clarify the activation of the nature of evil roots.
Now, within the activation of evil dharmas,
it is still based on the five kinds of unwholesomeness to discern.
Among the unwholesome dharmas,
each has its own three.
The three fives are the fifteen unwholesome dharmas.
When discussing the activation of unwholesomeness by practitioners,
there is no definite sequence.
Now, based on the teaching,
it is discerned in order.
As fully listed above.
First, clarifying the characteristics of the activation of initial and sustained thought,
which are of three kinds.
First, the initial and sustained thought in the mind of clarity,ğŸ”½second, the initial and sustained thought in the mind that is half-clear and half-dark,
third, the initial and sustained thought in the mind that is completely deluded and confused.
As for the activation of initial and sustained thought in the mind of clarity,
if the practitioner has not deeply planted wholesome roots in the past,
when cultivating concentration,
They do not give rise to various wholesome dharmas at all.
They only have discursive thoughts and mental objects.
Moment by moment, they do not abide in the three poisons.
Nor do they have a specific object.ğŸ”½Sometimes they take greed as their object.ğŸ”½Sometimes they take anger as their object.
Sometimes they take delusion as their object.
But the things they take as objects
are clear and distinct.
In this way, even if they pass through years and months,
they do not give rise to various meditative absorptions.
This is the characteristic of discursive thoughts arising in a clear and sharp mind.
Second, discursive thoughts in a mind that is half-clear and half-dark:
If a person, when concentrating their thoughts,
although they are aware of the afflictions of discursive thoughts,
moment by moment they do not abide,
but according to the time of the object,
sometimes it is clear and sometimes it is dark.
When it is clear, discursive thoughts and mental objects
are not still.
When it is dark, it is indeterminate and dull,
without any awareness.ğŸ”½This is called the characteristic of discursive thoughts arising in a mind that is half-clear and half-dark.
Third, discursive thoughts in a mind that is completely dull and dark:
If a practitioner, during the cultivation of samÄdhi,
Although the mind is dull and dark, as if in sleep,
Yet within the state of dullness,
One clings to it tightly.
Discursive thoughts do not cease.
This is called the characteristic of the affliction of discursive thoughts in the mind of sinking dullness.
Second, clarifying the three kinds of characteristics of the arising of lust.
First, external lust.
Second, internal and external lust.
Third, lust pervading everywhere.
First, the characteristic of the arising of the affliction of external lust.
If a practitioner, when cultivating samÄdhi,
The mind of lust arises.
If it is a man,
Then it takes the woman as its object.
If it is a woman,
Then it takes the man as its object.
Grasping at their appearance, figure,
Demeanor, and speech,
The mind of afflictions arises.
Thoughts do not cease for a moment.ğŸ”½This is the characteristic of the arising of the affliction of external lust.
Second, the characteristic of the arising of the affliction of internal and external lust.
If a practitioner, during the cultivation of samÄdhi,
has lustful thoughts arise,
either due to external male and female bodies, appearances, postures, and mannerisms,
giving rise to attachment,
or else due to one's own body and appearance,
stroking the head, wiping the neck, moment by moment being stained and attached,
giving rise to various desires and attachments,
this then obstructs various samÄdhis.
This is the appearance of the arising of internal and external lustful afflictions.
Third, the arising of lustful afflictions that pervade everywhere,
this person is attached to the internal and external as before,
and further gives rise to desire and attachment to all five sense objects and resources.
Either lusting after fields, gardens, houses,
clothing, or drink,
in all places,
the appearance of lust arising.
Third, the appearance of the arising of anger,
there are also three kinds.
First, unreasonable anger,
second, reasonable anger,
third, anger arising from debate.
First, the arising of unreasonable anger,
If a practitioner, while cultivating concentration,
suddenly gives rise to the thought of anger,
regardless of whether it is reasonable or not,
whether the other person has committed an offense or not,
and becomes angry without reason,
this is the manifestation of the arising of unreasonable and deviant anger.
Second, the arising of reasonable and proper anger:
If, while cultivating concentration,
an outsider truly comes to disturb and provoke,
and on this basis gives rise to the thought of anger,
and it continues without cease,
it is also like a person who upholds the precepts, who sees those who violate the precepts
and gives rise to anger.
Therefore, the MahÄyÄna teaches:
In the pure buddha lands,
although there are no deviant three poisons,
there are the correct three poisons.
Now, the one who is said to be in accord with reason and has proper anger,
is precisely this kind of person.
Third, the anger of disputes over theories:
When a practitioner, while cultivating meditation,
becomes attached to the Dharma that they understand as being correct,
and considers everything that others practice and speak
to be incorrect.
Since what outsiders speak of
If it does not accord with one's own feelings,
then the mind of vexation arises.
There are people in the world who,
although their wealth and silk are encroached upon,
can still endure a little.
If they argue about principles,
then they become greatly angry and resentful.
They do not associate with each other.
This is called the appearance of anger arising from disputes.
Fourth, clarifying the appearance of delusion arising.
There are three kinds of its own.
First, calculating annihilation and permanence.
Second, calculating existence and non-existence.
Third, calculating the nature of the world.
These three are all attached to various wrong views.
They do not transcend birth and death.
Therefore, they are collectively called delusion.
First, the delusion of calculating annihilation and permanence.
The practitioner suddenly gives rise to wrong thoughts while cultivating concentration.
The mind of profit discriminates,
Do the present self and dharmas exist because the past self and dharmas ceased,
or do they exist without ceasing?
Because of this thought,
the mind of views immediately arises, and one investigates the three periods of time.
If one says they ceased, then one falls into annihilation.
If one says it does not cease, one falls into the extreme of permanence.
Such deluded thoughts
do not abide for a moment.
Because of this sharp and swift wisdom,
one's eloquence is unhindered, but one engages in disputes and frivolous debates.
One engages in various evil actions.
It obstructs the correct samÄdhi and the Dharma of leaving the world.
This is the characteristic of the deluded thought of grasping at annihilation and permanence arising.
Second, as for the deluded thought of grasping at existence and non-existence arising,
also, when cultivating samÄdhi,
one suddenly discriminates,
contemplates, and analyzes,
thinking, Are my aggregates and other dharmas now definitely existent,
or are they definitely non-existent,
or are they neither existent nor non-existent?
In this way, the mind that seeks to understand suddenly arises.
Following the views, one grasps them,
taking them as the correct and real deluded thoughts.
They do not abide for a moment.
Because of this sharp and swift wisdom,
one engages in frivolous debates and disputes,
giving rise to various wrong practices.
It obstructs the correct samÄdhi,
preventing it from developing.
This is the characteristic of the deluded thought of grasping at existence and non-existence arising.
Third, the manifestation of delusion arising from the nature of the world.
Also, during the time of cultivating concentration,
suddenly give rise to this thought:
Because there are subtle particles, there are real dharmas.
Because there are real dharmas,
there are the four great elements.
Because there are the four great elements,
there are the provisional names of sentient beings and the various worlds.
Contemplate in this way,
and the mind that gives rise to views is activated.
It does not abide moment by moment.
Because of this sharp wisdom and eloquence,
one is able to ask questions and expound the Dharma.
The mind becomes arrogant,ğŸ”½and one engages in disputes and arguments.
One exclusively engages in deviant practices,
departing from the true path.
Even the momentary mind of contemplation and discrimination
is also like this.
For these causes and conditions,ğŸ”½one is unable to give rise to various meditative absorptions.
Even if one gives rise to meditative absorptions,
one falls into the category of deviant concentration.
This is the characteristic of the manifestation of delusion arising from the nature of the world.
Fifth, the characteristics of the manifestation of the obstacles of evil karma on the path.
There are also three kinds.
First, the obstacle of sinking, confusion, and obscurity.
Second, the obstacle of evil thoughts and contemplations.
Third, the obstacle of being oppressed by objects.
The first is the obstacle of sinking, confusion, and obscuration.
When practitioners are cultivating concentration,
when they want to use their minds,
they immediately sink, become confused, and fall asleep.
They are blank and unaware of anything.
This obstructs all meditative concentrations,
and they cannot be developed.
This is the characteristic of the arising of the obstacle of sinking, confusion, and obscuration.
Second, the obstacle of evil thoughts and contemplations.
When practitioners want to cultivate concentration,
although they do not sink, become confused, or fall asleep,
evil thoughts arise in their minds.
They may think of committing the ten evil deeds, the four grave offenses, the five heinous crimes, violating the precepts, or returning to lay life, and so forth.
There is no time when they temporarily stop.
Because of this, it obstructs all meditative concentrations,
and they cannot be developed.
This is the characteristic of the arising of the obstacle of evil thoughts and contemplations. The third is the obstacle of being oppressed by objects.
When practitioners are cultivating concentration,
although there are no above matters,
their body may suddenly ache at times.
One feels oppressed.
One sees various external objects.
One may see headless, handless, footless, eyeless, etc.
One may see one's clothes torn.
One may sink into the ground.
Or fire may come to burn one's body.
One may see a high cliff and fall from it.
Two mountains block the way.
RÄká¹£asas, tigers, and wolves.
Or one may dream of various evil signs.
Such things are all due to the arising of obstructing sins that oppress the practitioner.
They may cause fear.
Or sometimes suffering.
There are various kinds like this.
They cannot be fully described.
This is called the characteristic of the arising of the obstruction of oppression by objects.
Now, regarding these five unwholesome dharmas,
they are combined into three obstacles.
The first three poisons
are the obstacle of afflictions as the cause of habits, and the disturbed dharmas of contemplation within the equal parts.
This is because they are the coarse four aggregates.
It is called the obstacle of retribution.
The three kinds of obstacles that block the path
are the obstacle of karma.
How do we know this?
Because of creating evil in the past,
in the future one should receive evil retribution.
One then holds onto this evil through karma.
If the practitioner, in the period between not yet receiving retribution,
cultivates goodness,
goodness and evil are incompatible.
Karma then supports evil and arises,
coming to obstruct goodness.
Therefore, one should know that this is precisely the obstacle of karma.
Such are the three obstacles.
They obstruct all practitioners' meditation and wisdom,
not allowing them to develop.
Therefore, they are called obstacles.
Third, next, clarifying the Dharma of counteracting.
Counter means the main counter.
Treating is called the treatment.
Like the main treatment of the contemplation of impurity for sexual desire, it is called counteracting.
Like this, up to the samÄdhi of mindfulness of the Buddha,
the main treatment for the obstacle of evil karma.
Now, in clarifying the counteracting,
there are six different meanings.
First, the treatment of counteracting.
Second, the treatment of transformation.
Third, the treatment of non-transformation.
Fourth, combined treatment.
Fifth, combined transformation.
Combined non-transformation treatment.
Sixth, non-opposition.ğŸ”½Non-transformation, non-combined treatment.
The first is the treatment.
The previous good and evil roots give rise to the middle,
Which is called fifteen.
Now in this treatment,
It is also fifteen.
The question is:
Isn't this redundant?
The answer is: it is not so.ğŸ”½The previous was said in order to verify and understand.
Now it is said in order to treat.
The previous was said because the good roots arise by themselves.
Now it is said in order to cultivate.
This is not redundant.
The first is the treatment for those with many illnesses of coarse and fine thoughts.
As it is said in the sutra:
For those with many coarse and fine thoughts,
They are taught to count the breath.
Now the illness of coarse and fine thoughts,
Since there are three kinds,
The breath as the treatment,
Is also for three meanings.
The first is the clear mind coarse and fine thoughts.
When the practitioner is sitting,
The clear mind clings to objects,
Moment by moment, it does not abide.
This should be taught to count the breath.
Why is it so?
The method of counting the breath.
Fix the mind on the breath.
The breath is the excellent medicine for treating chaos.
If one can count from one to ten,
without forgetting in the middle,
one will surely attain concentration.
One can break through chaotic thoughts.
The method of counting the breath.
In a state of deep concentration,
record the number in a state of deep concentration.
This can treat clarity and sharpness.
Therefore, counting the breath can cure the illness of conceptual thoughts in a state of clear and sharp mind.
Second, treating the illness of conceptual thoughts that are half clear and half dark,
the symptoms are as explained above.
Now, the method of treatment.ğŸ”½One should be taught to follow the breath.
Follow the inhalation and exhalation.
Then the mind always relies on the breath.
Because of relying on the breath,
if the breath is coarse, the mind becomes coarse; if the breath is subtle, the mind also becomes subtle.
The subtle breath comes and goes.
Continue to be mindful of it.
It can break through conceptual thoughts.
The mind becomes still and clear.
One knows the inhalation and exhalation of the breath,
its length and shortness, its coming and going.
The illumination and application are clear.
One is able to break through dullness and torpor.
Therefore, it is said to be following.
If one only counts the breath,
there is the fault of supporting dullness.
If one only observes the breath,
there is also the loss of floating and distraction.
It is not called good counteraction.
Third, in the mind that treats dullness and torpor, there is alertness and contemplation.
The signs of the arising of alertness and contemplation
are as explained above.
The method of counteracting
should be taught to observe the breath.
When the breath enters,
carefully observe where this breath comes from.
What does it pass through in the middle? Where does it enter and abide?
Exhaling through the mouth is also like this.
This method will be explained in detail later.
In this way, seeking its root source,
there is no dispersal upon leaving,
no accumulation upon entering.
One does not see any fixed thoughts.
The mind of clear observation opens the eye of the mind.
It breaks through dullness and torpor.
Relying on the breath with a tranquil mind.
Can break up scattered thoughts.
Therefore, using the contemplation of the breath to counteract the illnesses of sinking, dullness, and discursive thoughts.
Second, treating the illness of excessive sexual desire.
As it is said in the sutras:
Those with excessive sexual desire,
Are taught the contemplation of impurity. Since sexual desire has three types,
The countermeasures are also for three purposes.
First, treating those with excessive external sexual desire,
The illness arises from attachment to external objects, the appearance, manner, and smooth skin of men and women.
Therefore, the fire of lust burns incessantly.
The method of counteraction,
One should be taught to practice the nine contemplations.
If one goes to a charnel ground and takes the appearance of a corpse,
One should also contemplate the attractive objects,
Falling onto the ground.ğŸ”½Observing the bloated and rotting corpse,ğŸ”½With pus and blood flowing out,
Feces and urine,
And worms gnawing at it.
Now, I who am attached,
Am also like this.
Where is there anything attractive?
Having contemplated in this way,
The mind of lust will naturally cease.
Therefore, the nine contemplations can cure the serious illness of lust and attachment to external objects.
Second, it cures the afflictions of greed and lust both internally and externally.
The symptoms of the arising of afflictions are as explained above.
If one wishes to cure them,
One should be taught to contemplate the first stage of discarding the body and so forth.
Contemplate the impurity, destruction, and repulsiveness of one's own body,
And immediately break the attachment to the internal.
Then, as before,
Contemplate the external impurity and repulsiveness, and immediately detach from attachment to external objects.
This is the first stage of discarding the body.
With this impure mind, contemplate internal and external forms,
And be able to break the illness of attachment and lust both internally and externally.
Third, it cures those who give rise to greed and attachment everywhere.
The symptoms of the arising of the illness of greed are as explained above.
The method of curing should teach contemplating the great impurity everywhere.
Contemplate all objects, the bodies of men, women, oneself, and others, fields, gardens, houses, clothing, and food and drink,
All the things in the world are seen as impure, and there is not a single place where one can give rise to a greedy mind.
At that time, in all places,
one gives rise to a mind of disgust and detachment.
Then all greed and desire
will have no place to arise again.
This is called the remedy for the illness of greed and desire in all places.
Third, the treatment for the illness of excessive anger.
As it is said in the sÅ«tras:
Those who are excessively angry
are taught to cultivate the meditation on loving-kindness to treat the illness of anger.
Since there are three kinds,
the remedies also have three aspects.
First, the treatment for wrongful anger.
Day and night, the mind thinks of unreasonable ways to harm others with evil things, and the characteristics of anger arise.
As explained above, the treatment should be to cultivate the loving-kindness that takes sentient beings as its object. Take the characteristics of a close person obtaining happiness.
Take this as the object and enter concentration.
In this way, within seeing a close person obtaining happiness,
all resentful people, etc., are made to obtain happiness.
Take the characteristics of others obtaining happiness.
One is able to give rise to affection and care.
It immediately destroys the mind of anger, resentment, and harm towards sentient beings.
Second, the treatment for the main anger is as follows.
If there is no angry mind at all towards other matters,
but only anger arises when seeing others committing evil or violating precepts, the symptoms of the illness are as explained above.
The treatment should teach the cultivation of
the dharmic object of compassion, contemplating the emptiness and falsity of the five skandhas.
Not seeing sentient beings,
how can there be right and wrong matters of upholding precepts or not?
Only taking the dharma joy within all feelings
and giving it to others,
with a compassionate and loving mind,
one should not add to the harm.ğŸ”½When right and wrong are eliminated,
the angry mind naturally ceases.
This is called practicing the dharmic object of compassion, which can treat the illness of anger that accords with principles.
Third, the treatment for the anger that arises from disputes over all dharmas is as follows.
The symptoms of the illness are as explained above.
The method of treatment
should teach the cultivation of the signless compassion.
Why is it so?
This person, according to the dharmas they have attained,
Having considered oneself to be right,
one considers others to be wrong.
Those who agree with oneself are pleased,
while those who oppose oneself become angry.
One may give rise to attachment within the four propositions or beyond the four propositions,
or one may again become attached to the middle way.
In this way, there is something to rely upon,
and thus there is contention and clinging due to causes and conditions.
One then gives rise to the perception of anger.
The method of counteracting this is
to cultivate the compassion of no-thought.
When practicing this compassion,
the path of speech is cut off,
and the realm of mental activity ceases.
With regard to all phenomena,
one neither recollects nor thinks of them.
If there is no recollection,
due to what contention and argument would an angry mind arise?
Great compassion is impartial,
equally bestowing the bliss of inherent purity.
Because it is free from the aspect of harming others,
it is called compassion that bestows bliss.
It can also be said that the bodhisattva expounds such a Dharma for sentient beings,
which is called great compassion.
One should know that the cultivation of compassion of no-thought
counteracts all contention and anger towards phenomena.
Fourth, for those with much delusion and illness.
As it is said in the sutras:
Those with much delusion
Should contemplate dependent origination.
Question:
The principle of dependent origination
Is very profound.
How can those with much delusion
Be taught to contemplate dependent origination?
Answer:
Those with much delusion
Do not refer to cattle, sheep, and the like.
They are simply people who are intelligent and have sharp faculties,
But who do not attain right wisdom through discrimination and deliberation.
Their deluded minds grasp at principles,
Which is called the illness of delusion.
Since there are three kinds of illnesses,
The remedies should also be established as three.
First, for the illness of delusion regarding annihilation and permanence,ğŸ”½One may give rise to the view of permanence
Or the view of annihilation.
One then destroys cause and effect.
The symptoms of the illness are as explained above.
The method of remedy
Is to teach one to contemplate the twelve links of dependent origination in the three periods of time.
The past has two,
The present has eight,
And the future has two.
These are the twelve links of dependent origination.
The three periods of time are mutually dependent.
They are neither permanent nor annihilated.
As a verse in the sutra says:
In my true Buddhist Dharma, although empty, it is not annihilated.
The continuity is also not permanent. Good and evil are also not lost.
If practitioners are able to skillfully contemplate the twelve links of dependent origination,
They will not cling to annihilationism or eternalism.
Then the mind of wrong views will cease.
They can also use this to eliminate the delusion of the provisional continuity of phenomena.
Second, the treatment for the delusion of the disease of attachment to existence and nonexistence is as follows.
Wrong thoughts and contemplations give rise to the idea of self and non-self,
The existence and non-existence of the aggregates, and so forth.
As explained above.
As for establishing the counteragent,
One should be taught to contemplate the twelve links of dependent origination in terms of karmic retribution.
As for the twelve links of dependent origination in terms of karmic retribution,
One contemplates the time of kalala in the present.
This is called ignorance.
Up to birth, old age, and death, and so forth.
The present is endowed with the five aggregates, twelve sense fields, and eighteen elements.
All arise from causes and conditions.
At the time of this kalala,
there are already three things:
life, warmth, and consciousness.
Therefore, it is called ignorance.
Since this arises from conditions,
it has no self-nature.
It cannot be said to exist.
It cannot be said to not exist.
Up to old age and death are also like this.
If one knows it is neither empty nor existent,
then one breaks the two views of emptiness and existence.
One should know that the contemplation of the twelve links of dependent origination in terms of karmic retribution
treats the illness of the views of existence and non-existence.
Now, one can also use this to counter
and destroy the delusion of grasping at the provisional as real due to clinging to causes.
Third, in treating the delusion of the nature of the world,
if one sees a subtle nature
that can give rise to myriad dharmas,
such a deluded thought
is called the view of the nature of the world.
It is explained in detail as above.
The method of treatment
is to still contemplate the twelve links of dependent origination in a single thought.
Why is it so?
The practitioner deeply contemplates that within a single thought, the twelve are complete,
but one is not the twelve.
Twelve, not one.ğŸ”½Now, based on one, twelve are spoken of.
Based on twelve, one is spoken of.
One should know that one has no fixed nature.
Since there is no fixed one,
The nature of the world cannot be obtained.
Therefore, using the contemplation of the twelve conditions in a single thought,
One can destroy the false views that grasp at the nature of the world.
This contemplation of the twelve conditions in a single thought,
Destroys many of the views that grasp at oneness and difference.
Now, one can also use this to destroy the delusions of dependent falseness.
Fifth, it cures the many illnesses of the path obstructed by evil karma.
As it is said in the sutras,
Those who are obstructed on the path,
Are taught to contemplate the Buddha.
Now, since there are three kinds of obstructions on the path,
The countermeasures also establish three.
First, it cures those who give rise to the obstruction of sinking, confusion, and darkness.
The signs of illness of evil karma are as explained above.
The countermeasure should teach them to contemplate one of the thirty-two marks of the Buddha.
First, take the mark between the Buddha's eyebrows.
Close the eyes and contemplate.
If the mind is dark and dull,
If you do it while lying down, it will not be accomplished.
You should face a good and dignified image.
Single-mindedly take the characteristics.
Take that as the object and enter concentration.
If it is not clear,ğŸ”½then open your eyes and observe again.
Then close your eyes again.
In this way, take one characteristic and make it clear.
Then observe all the characteristics in sequence.
Make the mind's eye open and clear.
Then it will break through the mind of dull sleep and sinking darkness.
Recalling the Buddha's merits will remove karmic hindrances.
Question:
If you take the characteristics and make them clear,
and can break through dullness and confusion,
why not practice the nine contemplations on the white bones, etc.?
Answer:
The nine contemplations on the white bones
are just the impure body of birth and death.
The meaning of removing offenses is inferior, so it is not a remedy.
Second, the treatment of the hindrance of evil thoughts and contemplations.
The hindrance to giving rise to [the mind of enlightenment] is as explained above.
The remedy should be taught to recall the Buddha's merits.
What does it mean to recall?

The mind of right mindfulness contemplates the Buddha's ten powers, four fearlessnesses, eighteen distinctive abilities, and all-encompassing wisdom that illuminates the Dharma realm, always tranquil and unmoving, universally manifesting the physical body to benefit all, with immeasurable and inconceivable merits and virtues.
When contemplating in this way,
this is the remedy.
